response.answer_text: I write for a number of reasons. This answer might get a little heavy, but i just needed to get it out of my system so i apologise. Writing means different things to different people. For some, it’s a way to get things out of their system. They write to give their depression a kick in the ass and say “not today, bitch”, and I can relate to that. People also write because it’s a spur of the moment thing. You could be sitting on a train, but your mind is racing thinking of that Marvel fanficion you’re going to publish later on Wattpad. It helps you through the day and keeps you motivated and thats why people write. I would like to think I’m a mix of both. Recently (okay more like today), I read a book called Every Last Word. It’s about a girl names Samantha who has severe OCD, and how she finds a place for herself and discovers herself through the process of writing poetry. To quote the author, it’s about saying gooodbye too people who have had a huge place in your past, but know they don’t belong in your future. Most importantly, its a story about the healing power of words. (Did I mention I cried my heart out at the end of the story? Well know y’all know. WHEEHEE.) Through the story, I’m reminded about how i write to get things out of my system. I’m not clinically diagnosed with depression, but sometimes i damn well feel like i need someone to talk to but the hard truth is — sometimes, no one is there. I don’t want to hurt anyone with my pain, so what do i do? I take refuge in words. Short stories, which one day i might share with y’all wonderful people on this website. Poetry. Songs. Everything. I centralised my story on my pain and write from there. Writing means something to everyone and to me, it means expressing myself in ways I could never speak out. It means letting my imagination run wild and free with no one there to judged me for being weird and childish. Maybe one day through writing, I’ll discover myself. Just like Samantha did.

Why do I write? The short answer is that I write because I can’t not write. There are many other ways that I can preoccupy my time (eg. reading a novel—which only takes me a Saturday to do—watching Youtube or Netflix, texting, going out… you get the picture), but out of all those options I choose to write. Not only because I just have so many ideas that I want to share with the world and I chose writing as my medium, but also because I’d be letting myself down if I didn’t write at least a little bit a day. Four years ago, during my Golden Age of Writing, I wrote every day for hours, to the point where I realized I was hungry only when I got off of the computer. A ton of stories were being created as ideas kept on popping up, sometimes 2 or more in the same week; they never got finished, but the point is that I was writing. Then my stories began to get more complex as I focused on a particular one, I started to think about adding layers to my stories, began working on some full-length novels, and suddenly, I wasn’t writing as much as I had during my Golden Age. I’d been lost in the sea of complication that I forgot to just write. When I reflected on that, I set up my personal goal of writing at least a little bit a day; I write way more than a little bit (especially I now have the time to do so!), but I want to keep pushing myself. Get back to the Golden Age-style practice, while also keeping my modern day complexity. I just write to get better. Another reason (and this is one that I feel is cliche but also very necessary) is that I just love writing. As previously mentioned, I can take care of my time any other way, yet I write. I’ve been writing ever since I was 10 (16 now!) and I feel in love with the freedom, the creativity that I could have while writing. Yes there are rules to abide by, but I can make those rules work for me and my purposes. I love coming up with new ideas (my eyes light up and I jump up and down and get really giddy and happy and excited when I do), finding ways to add twists on old ideas (repeat previous parenthetical), and I even love the editing too sometimes, despite other authors seeing it as a necessary evil. It may be a daunting task and take forever but there are times where I’ve looked over a passage that I wrote and said “wow, this is actually nice.” I’ve also connected with other people through it. Not just through Quora, but I’ve touched base with a lot of people that I honestly consider dear friends because of our creative outlets, whether it be writing, acting, drawing… I literally just made a plan with some of my coworkers to make an anime one day; I’ll do the script while another does the animations and we already have one person as a voice actor! Not to mention the impacts these people have on you. My writing’s connected me to these foreigners and have made them people that I can trust, that I can and will go to advice for anything about. And is there another reason I write? There are probably a ton of reasons, ranging from “I’ve been doing it ever since I was really little” to “I want success” (which isn’t that big a reason for me since I’d do it for free) to even “I’ve come to far to quit” and “so many people want me to continue writing”. So, to sum this up, I write because it’s amazing. It’s great for me creatively, it gives me more of a purpose, improves my work ethic and make me want to do better for myself, and is just overall really refreshing. It may be hard, but in the end it’s worth it. So long as your heart’s in the writing and you reflect on why you want to write, if you want to write, and what your passions are at least once every few months or so, you’ll do fine. And even if it’s not writing, just find A passion. Find something you love doing and push for it. Good luck! And (hopefully) happy writing!
